reviewText: Let me start by saying that this movie is beautiful. The costumes, the locations, all are done marvelously and Franklyn is a feast for the eyes. The visual style and costumes also fit each character very well. If you are getting this movie, get it on blu ray. I think the visuals are this movie's strongest points.I can not say to much about what this film is about without giving away spoilers. It is about four people, a father looking for a lost son, a young man left by his bride before the wedding, a young woman devastated by the loss of her father, leading her to play with suicide for an art project and a masked vigilante living in a steam punk like alternate reality. The movie being s very confusing but do come together in the end. I think the plot of this movie was ok, it deals with topics like insanity, imagination and religion and the story is not bad, I however also think the story got boring at times, the movie moved to slowly.Now here is my main problem with this film, there are to many characters, in effect this is four films in one, if they had just cut one or two of the characters then everything would have been so much better. On that note I think the character Emilia is completely unnecessary. The other three character's storyline come together in the end, Emilia is just there, it is like the director decided he had to have a female character in the last possible moment and just threw one in without any sort of planning.Franklyn is a beautiful film, the story is rather ok and the characters are interesting. I say this film is rather ok. It was not completely my cup of tea, but if movies more on the artsy side suits you I think you will like this. I do not like artsy movies and I still found this entertaining. The movie is has some phasing problems, but in the end I think it is rather good.
summary: Artsy film with a decent story.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Once in a blue moon, a film comes along that defies genre identification ...and so goes FRANKLYN, a movie that transcends anything you think you've ever seen. A hybrid in terms of style, Franklyn might best be described as Frank Miller (the artist) meetsThe Dark Knight(Batman) inBrazil(the movie). I say this because none of these items alone help explain the convoluted-ness that is this story, and none should. It goes beyond them. Way beyond them.Visually appealing on almost every level, Franklyn has two divergent stories that seem to have nothing to do with each other. In one we're privy to a kind of superhero trying to avenge the death of a young girl whom we know nothing about. He chases after "The Individual" in a city known as Meanwhile. Looking, as stated earlier, somewhere along the lines of a Frank Miller graphic mixed with a kind of Dark Knight quality, the story intrigues and makes us cheer on the main character, Jonathan Preest (Ryan Philleppe,Flags of Our Fathers). I mean, trying to avenge the death of an innocent girl is noble, right? Equally intriguing within the city of Meanwhile are the many religions that flourish, including the Seventh Day Manicurists. Everyone is required to have a religious affiliation ...except our "hero" who is subsequently tracked by highly skilled fighting monks.In the second story, a woman named Emilia (Eva Green,The Golden Compass) tries to come to terms with her life and her art. She consistently tries to kill herself for the sake of it only to learn that her art just isn't inspiring enough. Also, a man in search of his missing son comes to the psychiatrist who'd been treating him only to learn that his son escaped and is out in the world with a rifle slung over his shoulder.As the two storylines begin to mesh, reality skews, men and women we thought we knew either don't exist, exist as something else, or are strictly symbols (including a janitor who plays a vital role). The fascination the viewer will feel at the realizations of what is coming will shock, delight and sink their heart. Yes, it's THAT good.The visuals are what will initially draw you in. You'll be asking yourself "Why?" many times: Why is the city so muted? Why is he wearing a mask? Why are these religious fanatics chasing him? If you pay close attention, everything is answered in one final scene which, in itself, reveals amazing storytelling.I can't stress enough how closely everything is linked in the film and how paying attention reaps great benefits in the end. Even the names of the characters (Preest, The Individual, Wormsnakes, Pastor Bone) all have relevance.Made on a paltry $12 million budget, the movie feels much more expensive and expansive. Sadly, it did not get a wide release and suffered because of it. Not many people have ever heard of it. I know I never had until a friend I work with mentioned it. But I'm glad he pointed me in the right direction. This one's a hidden gem. And it's so original that you'll wonder which genre you're watching. I'm still wondering!
summary: Frank Miller Meets The Dark Knight Meets Brazil

reviewText: I had never heard of this film before = it is British-made, and I don't think it ever received a wide-US release in Theaters.But I saw it on DVD recently ==> and what a sharply imaginative, thought-provoking film it is!!It's interesting that some of the most intelligent, expertly crafted & original (complex & multi-Layered) Movies go almost completely unnoticed by average film-goers = I can think of the following four, right off-hand: "The Life Before her Eyes";  "The East";  "Melancholia";  "The Luzhin Defence" and now this amazingly obscure Film called 'Franklyn'!'Franklyn' was written and directed by Gerald McMorrow (produced in 2008) on a rather limited budget of only 6 million (roughly $10 million American).  It stars  Ryan Phillippe as the titular character (usually behind an unrevealingly simplistic, but foreboding Mask) - but the real human Star of this film, who gives a remarkably intricate and multi-layered performance is Eva Green (from James Bond 'Casino Royale' and the new Showtime series 'Penny Dreadful').  Eva generates (actually in dual roles) = profoundly haunting, mysteriously deeply penetrating performance(s)!The Story reflects an incredibly complex jigsaw-puzzle (really of Four seemingly independent tales & characters) ==> that eventually converge into a singular critical mass/ instantaneous moment (with each seemingly disparate, Lonely and 'Lost' individual character playing a pivotal and irreplaceable role in the final revelation!)Telling anything further will result in giving away too much!  Although I also wanted to mention that the 'Visuals' of the anciently futuristic Theocracy called 'Meanwhile' City (in which the lonely masked vigilante-like character Franklyn lives) is quite amazing to behold (a cross-between Gotham City and the Vatican?!)One final word = it's a real shame about truly visionary, and risk-taking films like this one from Gerald McMorrow (and especially Vadim Perelman's inordinately Great, insightful, and even vitally important "The Life Before her Eyes" along with "The East" from Zal Batmanglij & Brit Marling; and von Trier's painfully haunting "Melancholia" also the "Luzhin Defence" by director Marleen Gorris, with John Turturro as Nabokov's brilliant but unstable Chess-Master!)  Why can't these films find a Sizable audience (they are sadly quite unknown, although very deserving of much Wider viewership) - while the hopelessly 'formulaic' stuff tends to make hundreds of millions of dollars*!!note*: of course there are exceptionally well-crafted (and even artistic) Blockbusters, like "X-Men: Days of Future Past" and "Watchmen" and once in a great while, a special film does make an unexpected connection with wider audiences, like "Pan's Labyrinth**"!note**: "Pan's Labyrinth" was made by Guillermo del Toro in Mexico & Spain (not Hollywood) and produced on a modest budget ==> but I think it's better and more insightful than nearly all similar 'Fantasy/horror' films costing 10x as much!!  Same with 'Franklyn' (i.e. more intriguingly thought-provoking and even more entertaining than similar films costing 10x as much, or more = Should have gotten a proper US release!)
summary: Unknown but Compelling, Complex & Original (even profoundly Haunting) Film!

reviewText: not in a good way.  The two main male characters create alternate worlds to cope with their misery and pain; the main woman character is trapped in the now and consumed with her misery.  Misery is this woman's reason for being -- she paints it, she draws it, she films it, she inflicts it on everyone she comes into contact with.  At the end of the film, one of the miserable men meets up with the miserable woman in the middle of a miserable rainstorm and I guess they hook up and live happily ever after.

reviewText: I was very excited by the previews for this film.  It looked viscerally captivating, mysterious, and ominous.  And half of it was.  The movie follows two separate worlds, and I wish they simply left the one half dealing with our world out of it.  The movie had great promise, and I am convinced that if they were to redo this movie, focusing only on the visually striking world, it would be a massive success.All in all, though, it's a good movie to watch.  I would definitely watch it again, but I think I would just chapter skip to the parts which interested me.

reviewText: This movie takes on two realities, and ties 4 stories into one by the end.So in the alternate "Meanwhile City" is a figure like Rorshach from Watchmen, living in a city like Dark City, with a belief system and clerics a bit like equlibrium (and 1984 for that matter). The overlying story in the London is a bit like the movie "Spider".  The acting is quite good and tells the great story of a borderline personality disorder young woman who comes from an entitled family trying to earn the respect of her mother in the face of a horrible childhood. Mix this in with a gilted man who was stood up during his wedding plans, and a father who is looking for his missing son.  This movie is things done before put together in a new way to make it worth while seeing.  I have the dvd format, and upscaled it does not look bad, but I'm sure blu ray would have looked better. The visual effects are matrix like. If you are a fan of any of the above movies mentioned, worth a watching, but a bit predictable.
summary: Entertaining,but a mix of things done before.

reviewText: I thought the acting in this movie was very realistic, it was good enough to where it seemed like I was watching, somebodies real life story..Video quality was really good.The story itself... was extremely unique in the way it was done. But honestly, just because it was unique, didn't make it a great movie. The plot twist were more annoying than actually being something worth while.I would of rather our main guy. The one who wears the mask, of been a cliche'd hero. Because it would of been better. But it turns out, its a whole another deal.. He's not really a hero... etc.. I can't say much or I'd ruin the plot.I will say, it all comes together at the end, now is it a pretty bow? no, but it does come together a certain degree.Overall, its a decent movie. When the world switches over, to our Main guys world... He see's things differently, you have some really cool visuals. As someone who loves concept art, that made it worth while to me. If you like to be kept on your toes, and wondering whats going on... I'd say this movie is probably right up your ally.Movies are like books, its a matter of perspective. Just because I found the movie to be 'So So' don't let that scare you away. Rent it for yourself.
summary: Just because your Unique doesn't mean your great...

reviewText: Preest is an atheist vigilante hunting his nemesis through a futuristic dystopian city swept up in religious fervour; Milo, Emilia and Peter all exist in our world and are negotiating the travails of lost love, suicidal tendencies, and familial crisis on the streets of modern London. The lives of all four of these people are intrinsically entwined.Gerald McMorrow's "Franklyn" is one of those films that seems doomed to labour in obscurity despite the fact that it is thematically, conceptually, and aesthetically streets ahead of most of the awful drek that are heralded as modern classics by today's lazy critics.The work of Alan Moore is clearly an influence; as is that of Terry Gilliam (as well as "Dark City" and "Blade Runner").But this film is its own unique universe; and a brilliant one at that.Touching, subtle, labyrinthine and brilliantly executed and acted by an excellent cast, this is a stunning dark fantasy.

reviewText: This is really a very cool movie. You have 3 separate stories happening in modern day London and adjoining stories in the 'elsewhen' city of "Meanwhile." It took me a while to get my footing, but as the stories progressed, it started to gel. There are some problems other reviewers have noted. Yes, the characters could have been written better. Yes, the London scenes could have used some punching up on the script side. But there are so many more positives here I will forgive its shortcomings.The art direction is generally quite good (outstanding in the 'Meanwhile" scenes), and the costuming and music score are good as well. The religious based society in 'Meanwhile' is both funny and thought provoking. There is simply a wealth of stuff going on here. Yes, it could have been better but I'm as certain as I can be that repeated viewings will reveal many more subtleties in the connection between the two worlds.I haven't figured out how to delegate a half star in this rating system but this is definitely a 3 and a half for me and further viewings might up that to a four. If you're at all a fan of the 'elsewhen' type films this is a must.
summary: Maybe there's more to be seen

reviewText: It didn't take me but maybe ten minutes to realize there was something very dis-concerning with the story line. I began to suspect I was in for the big dupe and sure enough that was what I got. Like a funnel the movie starts with four different story lines making their way around each other as they descend to their climatic finale. Unfortunately the stories circle and circle and wait right unto the end where they are suddenly rushed together and with little sense at that. There some moments of visual brilliance but they are far to few to keep ones interest. The acting and cinematography were both top notch but alas with such a weak story underneath this film falls very flat. When I first heard about this movie it was one of those, audiences and critics missed out on this one, it slipped through the cracks but in truth I think it was thrown away and was deservedly ignored and forgotten. Once of the worst movies I have seen since having the rug pulled from under me in "High Tension".

reviewText: This one was a bit of a surprise for me. I decided to see this movie on dvd based on its cover art and the actors who were in it, which is a terrible way of choosing a movie to see. But this turned out to be a really great, and enjoyable film, excellently crafted and executed from start to finish. The story of the film follows four different characters and their intertwining paths, Milo the emotionally shattered lover, Emilia who is turning her self destruction into an art form, and the middle aged Peter who is looking for his estranged son. All of these previous characters stories take place in a modern day London, the fourth one, Jonathan Preest, takes place in the surreal Meanwhile City. Preest is a vigilante/criminal in a city of absurd faiths and is haunted by his failure to protect a young a girl.Its an all around solid movie, with great acting performances, interesting characters, a good story that does a good job of contrasting the Dark Fantasy elements with a cold hard reality, good costumes, sets, etc. Another thing I liked about this movie was that it borrows some themes from  Terry Gilliam's work in the 80s with the power of imagination, fantasy, and escapism but it still cutting its own way with the main focus on the sadness and personal misery that ultimately leads these characters to cross paths with each other in one form or another. Its not a happy movie, but not as depressing as I might be making it out to be. Its certainly entertaining, interesting, and visually put together serenely. Highly recommended.

reviewText: We will certainly be hearing from this writer/director again. His very first feature film demonstrates an impressive grasp of film narrative, photography, and editing - all accomplished with a dazzling visual flair.  Four characters are presented to us in parallel stories of lost souls who are searching for someone or something, and these characters gradually begin to connect with each other in intriguing ways until the final climactic scene. For many viewers, including this one, the best of these stories is set in Meanwhile City, an alternate world inspired by the genre called "Steampunk" (perhaps best described as a sort of gritty hyper-real Victoriana), here superbly realized with an incredibly detailed production design.  The director tells us in an interview (included in the extras) that those scenes were photographed with a different lens than the shots of contemporary London.  A similar attention to detail is evident in every frame of this film.The acting is excellent from all the principals and several minor characters as well.  The music is also very good.Frankly, and in so many ways, this brainy and courageous little film, made on a tiny budget and partially funded by the UK National Film Council, puts to shame most of the big Hollywood extravaganzas, and, on this Blu-ray disc, looks better than all of them.
summary: A Brilliant and Orginal film debut

reviewText: Perhaps a modern fairytale with a gothic twist?  This movie is hard to define.  It is a visually breathtaking film with great acting, a solid script with lots of thought provoking material.I would caution against reading reviews that give the plot away since it will ruin the experience of watching this film.  It starts with a dark view of a city called Meanwhile where all citizens MUST have religion and any without are persecuted.  A masked hero explains his need to avenge the death of a small child who was cruelly sacrificed to their God.  Then we flash to current times to meet a man who has just been jilted the day before his wedding and a troubled young woman who meticulously plans her suicide attempts for the benefit of her mother and "Art."  We watch these three main characters as their fates collide for one brief moment in Franklyn's flat.The beauty of this film - forgetting the cinematography for a moment - is the seamless blending of the two worlds by the end.  We discover who Sarah really is and how she was viewed to be sacrificed since it was explained as "God's will."  We see the young man's childhood playmate come back to him in his moment of need as lovingly explained by his mother.  We discover why the woman was so troubled.This movie is full of thought provoking moments.  As the troubled young woman toys with suicide and gets advice from someone who knows - it's not just about the lives you leave behind but the people who lives you've yet to touch. This movie does not attack religion but addresses one man's need to question after serving in Iraq and then suffering further loses once home.  Why do bad things happen to good people?  If God is able to change this, why would he choose not to?  Why honor a Malevolent God? If God not capable of changing these moments? Then why call him God?This movie shines despite it's darkness.  Our masked man John Priest sums up this movie best when he tells the audience that life is full of moments where fates collide to make for one happy moment and does not care how many bad things must happen to get there.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Franklyn" encompasses an interesting cross-section of genres. The film is composed of two worlds: Meanwhile City, brimming in sci-fi elements and painted in dark gothic tones with iron fisted religious fanaticism. This is paralleled by modern-day London, while seemingly mundane - having mysteries of it's own. Strong psychological elements bind Meanwhile City to modern day London, and the ending ties up "just enough" elements to satisfy, while leaving a few riddles open for discussion.One of the issues with the film, for some viewers, is the main character Franklyn. He appears mostly in trench coat with a uniquely stiched - almost featureless hood, save for large blackened eye sockets. It would seem that this stylistic choice holds too much baggage - E.G. invoking expectations approaching the Watchman's masked vigilante "Rorschach". While not a superhero, Franklyn is the tragically intriguing fulcrum of the film; Ryan Phillippe carries the part well. Interestingly enough, the promotional posters featured an unmasked version of Franklyn.The movie instantly engrosses viewers within the otherworldly Meanwhile city, and takes it's time wrapping modern-day London around you - all the while leading you to the subtle intersection of the worlds and characters. This is an intellectual journey through a science-fiction/ psychological-thriller. It's deeper than "The Book of Eli", but not quite as challenging as "Solaris".Intellectual sci-fi isn't for everyone. Combining the former with a psychological thriller is risky, and will certainly alienate some. Still - you have to commend the filmmakers for the job they did on such a limited budged.I hold well-done independent films in high regard and really wanted to rate this 4 stars, but the ending smacks of inevitability. It's not that there isn't a payoff, but rather that the film starts a lot stronger than it ends.

reviewText: **Some Spoilers - Be Aware**It's impossible to discuss Frankyln without some revealing some spoilers.  So, you are forewarned.you've had your chance to click away ...... review and spoilers next ....I've seen a bunch of reviews that compare "Franklyn" to "Dark City" or "Blade Runner" or "City of Lost Children".  And yes, there is some of that.  Its myriad-thread plot reminds me of the movie "Exotica," and if you like "Franklyn," consider watching "Exotica"( warning: Exotica contains copious amounts of nudity).  But "Franklyn" is fresh and original.  Therein lie some of its problems.This movie may offend some people who are easily offended about religion.  While the movie does poke fun at a myriad of nonsensical religions (the "bearded suits" outtake in the deleted scenes is a glimpse of the delicious direction this movie could have/should have gone if it had spent more time in Meanwhile City), the parody is in brilliant context.  David is a young man driven mad by the death of his sister.  David's churchman father has explained the girl's tragic death as "God's will."  Therefore, David retreats from the real world/London to his imaginary Meanwhile City, where he reimagines himself as the masked avenger John Preest and rebels against God and fate.This is revealed fairly early on.  And again, movies that happen in a character's head aren't unique, either.  But the problem with "Franklyn" is it keeps leaving Meanwhile City to dawdle through mundane London, where we watch competing plots unfold in the lives of Milo, a romantic young man who was jilted at the altar, and Emilia, a woman who is making suicide attempts as an art form. If you're like me, you'll end up wishing that Emilia succeeds sooner rather than later.  And Milo -- that boy needs to get laid.The lives of these mundane inhabitants of real-life London so pales next to Preest's adventures in Meanwhile City that you might want to fast-forward to the Steampunk.  However, there are important threads and clues you'll miss if you do.The movie raises some fascinating questions about the nature of reality.  It's better than half the crap made by big Hollywood studios.  And unlike many independent films, "Franklyn" is all wrapped up in the end (a bit too neatly).  So, it deserves 4 stars.Why not 5 stars?  In the end, while I found the movie fresh and original, it was too clever by half.  And when I start nit-picking before the movie is over, it's a sign the director has failed to capture me with his story.Did the following things bother you ...* If you've been shot by a sniper rifle, what are the odds you're going to start flirting with the next girl you meet while you are bleeding on the sidewalk?  Yeah, yeah, I know who she looks like, but still ... shot. Ouch!* And why is she attracted to a man bleeding on a sidewalk? Yes, I know ... fate/otherworldly connection.  Still.* How did David smuggle his service rifle into London anyway?  Hasn't he been in a mental hospital for 4 years?  And he supposedly served in Basra, but that rifle looks to be from an earlier conflict.  That's just sloppy writing.I don't think you'll be sorry for watching this movie. But you'll be wishing the director had gone in a different direction and spent the entire movie inside David's head, inside Meanwhile City.
Title: N/A

reviewText: You can't fault McMorrow's aspirations - FRANKLYN is an ambitious film, especially as a first-time feature, and although he's overstretched himself somewhat, this is an interesting piece of cinema. It owes debts to several more successful films, such as Dark City and V for Vendetta. The satire and imagery are a little heavy-handed, and it's miscast, with only Bernard Hill truly convincing in his role. And yet despite these faults it remains a compelling, if disjointed, story about fractured minds, destiny, and lovelorn loneliness.

reviewText: One of those films where even as the credits roll, you almost want to say WTF just happened mixed with knowing you just watched a great little movie.Story descriptions that I have read here and elsewhere can confuse more often than help, but a quick summary could include two "parallel" worlds in London converging over the course of the story, culminating in a final climactic event that ties all of the stories (real and imagined) together. Meanwhile, the visuals and sounds are conveyed eloquently and with outstanding Blu clarity. The picture is tested in every single Meanwhile City panoramic, and each time I would pause it to look for flaws and holes - but couldn't really find any. There are very few scenes with bright colors, but when they show up the saturation/contrast is just right. The DTS was ideal. Reference the scene with Ryan's character surrounding the snake guy, or any of the off-camera sounds being moved around the channels perfectly (answering machine shots, hospital sounds, etc.) Phillippe's voice does not the have the ideal inflections for a film-length narration, but you get through it because it is usually over the fantasy world sequences where you might spend more time looking at all they are putting before you.The supplements include:* A brief ad-plug style making of that should definitely be watched after the movie (gives away all of the twists).* Interviews. They all last 32 minutes total, and can be watched individually or as a play all. Main cast and crew are dryly interviewed on set, but they give some vital info on the inspiration, logistics and (appropriately) some of the confusion people have in trying to describe everything that is Franklyn.* Deleted scenes. Less than 10 minutes but I enjoyed seeing more of the red haired lady and her wonderful role.A very obscure and darkly anti-religious/faith film, but worth the watch if you would like a mix ofDark City (Director's Cut) [Blu-ray] meets a masked man noir narrative. Blu quality is superb - not the best I have seen but great overall for what this was.
Title: N/A

reviewText: **No Spoilers** , just this: the cover art is deceiving. This is no fantasy world, time travel adventure/thriller. It deals with serious, mature topics in the present and real world. So those expecting an escapist "Dark City" et al. genre will be sorely disappointed.The viewer is tossed right in the middle of four unrelated characters's lives each on the crest of life changing personal turmoil. Paced episodically, we have no history as to how the character reached that particular state in their life, but as the movie unfolds a workable sketch emerges just enough to satisfy our curiosity about that person's circumstance.The fun in watching this movie- and the principal motivating factor to continue viewing- lies in figuring out how will all these unrelated plot lines ultimately be tied in and reconciled. In this regard Franklyn succeeds in delivering an unexpected twist, but does so awkwardly.The main problem with this movie is that most of the characters are rather unsympathetic, superficial and self indulgent. It is difficult to form a bond with them or care much about their problems. The "fantasy future world" of religious dystopia offers the most satisfying experience, rich with atmosphere and some biting sarcasm. However, this "world" remains marginal to the overall theme.Because of this tepid interest in the characters, even as the build up to some inevitable conclusion, it's more about detached curiosity of how the writers will reconcile the plot rather than sincere involvement with the movie itself. Some will call the inclusion of Meanwhile City a tease, but what it represents is really a pun. Pity the whole of the movie didn't take place there.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Based on the trailer you might be expecting a lot of action, a brilliant vigilante movie taking place between altering universes, and a unique twist like that of Dark City. But alas it doesn't live up to what you, a viewer, might expect based on the trailer.Instead you get a drama with an unsatisfying twist you might or might not see coming. Personally, I saw the twist, but was hoping the twist that was there wouldn't be the twist.I still enjoyed the film, it had some really nice cinematography, and very good acting, but it left me wanting for something more. I wanted it to be a scifi superhero film, and it did have a fair amount of action, the movie just wasn't executed the way I wanted it to be.I know it sounds like I didn't really like the film, but I did. What it lacked for at the end it made up for with good dialogue, a fantastic score, some amazing shots, and really nice visual effects. I have a feeling this will become a cult classic, in the way that Donnie Darko did. Perhaps it will be the reverse of what happened with Donnie Darko, instead of this movie doing incredibly well in England, it will do incredibly well here.I'll admit that I forgot to mention there was one twist that was rather unexpected, but I'll share that in the comments section.edit: upon a few watches the movie gets better imo because the score really lifts up and really adds to the beauty.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Revolving around four lost souls and set in two parallel worlds, Franklyn certainly isn't the Dark City/superhero movie it was rather misleadingly sold as but a rather more ambitious variation on that old arthouse favourite, the apparent strangers who are gradually drawn to the same place and event that will impact differently on each of their lives. There's probably no more to it than meets the eye, but Gerald McMorrow moves and shoots his pieces so well that it's surprisingly satisfying to see them come together. If anything, despite its impressively designed if sparingly used fantasy scenes, the film is probably more influenced by Wim Wenders' Wings of Desire with its hints of people, possibly real, possibly not, who come into your life at the right time and then fade away.Eva Green is a troubled performance artist whose art project is built around filming her meticulously planned suicide attempts; Bernard Hill a church warden searching London for his missing son; Sam Riley an incurable romantic just jilted at the altar yet again and searching for his childhood sweetheart; and Ryan Philippe a masked atheist in a city of religious fanatics seeking revenge on the cult leader who killed a girl he was hired to protect. Gradually stories and actors (though not their roles) start to overlap, fantasies punctured and old wounds reopened or cauterised. Think about it too much and you'll probably be way ahead of the filmmakers, but go with the film at its own pace and it's surprisingly rewarding. McMurrow has a real visual sense that too few British filmmakers have: it's not just empty style or good looking shots for the sake of being good looking but in service of the story, characters and ideas. Those ideas may not be particularly deep or profound - ultimately little more than the need to acknowledge reality, however painful, rather than hiding in fantasy before you can move on - but they're delivered with sincerity and imagination and, with the partial exception of Riley's rather typically milquetoast turn, convincingly played.It'd be stretching it to say that Franklyn is a great film, but it is a great and encouraging directorial debut. It'll be interesting to see what McMorrow comes up with next.The Blu Ray has a decent selection of extras for a film that made so little impression at the box-office, including making of featurette and deleted scenes but not, sadly, McMorrow's 2002 short Thespian X which inspired the film.
summary: "If you believe in something strongly enough, who's to say if it's real or not?"
Title: N/A
